I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The  proposed  Sustainable  Urban  Development  and  Service  Delivery  Program  will 
enhance support to urban development in India by accelerating and implementing policy actions 
and urban reforms through mainstreaming performance-linked funding for urban service delivery. 
The proposed policy support aims to achieve universal and equitable access to urban services, 
which is consistent with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 and its operational 
priorities (OPs) of addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities (OP1); accelerating 
progress  in  gender  equality  (OP2);  tackling  climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster 
resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability (OP3); making cities more livable (OP4); 
and strengthening governance and institutional capacity (OP6).1 The program is also aligned with 
ADB’s country partnership strategy for India, 2018–2022, which envisages inclusive urbanization 
through policy advice and alignment with the government’s national programs.2 
 
2.  The Government of India requested financial support from ADB for urban national flagship 
programs being implemented by the Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs (MOHUA), and ADB 
has proposed a policy-based loan (PBL) from its ordinary capital resources (OCR) using a 
programmatic approach.3 The PBL has two subprograms of $350 million each to support policy 
actions in a sequential manner, ensuring that reforms are undertaken coherently both at the 
national and state levels within the PBL period (2021–2023). The modality is designed to support 
the implementation of policy actions that are crucial for structural reforms in the urban sector, with 
linkages to service delivery outcomes and local revenue improvements. Subprogram 1 will 
support policy reform actions under the newly launched (October 2021) national flagship program, 
the Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation (AMRUT) 2.0, by MOHUA; and 
recommendations of the 15th Finance Commission for revenue transfers to state agencies. 
Subprogram 2 will support the implementation of these reforms in the states and urban local 
bodies (ULBs). 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Urbanization in India. India’s urban population in 2020 was 460 million, the second 
largest in the world.4 The urban population is expected to grow by 2.01% per year over the next 
3 decades and is projected to reach 876 million by 2050.5 Although no systematic data for urban 
gross domestic product (GDP) are available, estimates of the urban share of GDP are 58%–70%.6 
The urban economy has grown because of growth in the services sector, which is estimated to 
account for more than 70% of the urban output. Despite the significant potential for serving as an

2 
engine of economic growth, Indian cities score very low on the Ease of Living Index 20217 and 
have not been able to maximize the economic benefits associated with increasing urbanization.8 
 
4.  Urban sector challenges. Urban residents lack access to basic services, resulting in poor 
urban service delivery and environmental sustainability. Only 56.9% of the urban households 
have piped water supply and only 53.5% are connected to an underground drainage system. The 
remainder dispose of their wastewater in covered surface drains (16.2%) or in an unsafe manner 
(27.8%).9 Wastewater treatment capacity is at 37% and untreated sewage is dumped into water 
bodies, polluting the environment. About 37.4% of urban households do not own a house and 17% 
of the urban population live in slums (2011). Women are worst affected by the unavailability or 
poor quality of the water, sanitation, and housing—creating unhealthy conditions and depriving 
them from income-generating activities. Of the world’s 50 most polluted cities in terms of air quality, 
25 are in India.10 India’s rapid urbanization is generating social and economic gains at the 
expense of risking environmental sustainability and public health. Unplanned urbanization has 
also exposed many people to increasing climate and disaster risks.  
 
5.  Institutional framework of the urban sector. The Government of India’s first guiding 
framework for urban governance reforms started with the 74th constitutional amendment of 1992, 
which provided a constitutional status to urban local governments as the third tier of governance. 
Urban planning and development are the responsibility of states, and various development 
authorities undertake planning and development for cities and urban regions under the town 
planning  acts  of  respective  states.  ULBs  implement  the  development  plans  and  urban 
development strategies that are approved by the state governments. ULBs are also responsible 
for providing urban services (e.g., water, sanitation, and solid waste management) from their 
revenue sources.11 
 
6.  The Government of India does not have jurisdiction over local governments or most of the 
matters related to urban areas. However, it has shaped the urban reform agenda and governance 
practices for promoting the economic development, investments, and competitiveness of cities. 
The government has consistently provided discretionary financial support through fiscal transfers 
to states and ULBs and through its national flagship programs. It has also encouraged states to 
increase their commitment to the urban sector. 
7.  Urban finance. Financial support from the national and state governments increased from 
0.35% of GDP in 2010–2011 to 0.45% of GDP in 2017–2018 because of increasing attention to 
and grant support for investments in urban infrastructure. While fiscal transfers through grants 
have increased, these have not resulted in improvements to local revenue generation, and ULBs’ 
dependence on fiscal transfers has increased.  The overall size of the municipal finance system 
is about 1.00% of GDP, of which ULBs’ own-source revenues comprise about 0.55% of GDP, 
showing ULBs’ high dependence on government support. Tremendous scope exists to enhance 
the own-source revenues of ULBs through reform measures such as enhancing property tax, as

3 
India has one of the lowest property tax–GDP ratios.12 Because of the lack of nationwide 
consensus on municipal finance reforms, the ULBs’ financial capacity continues to remain weak—
affecting  their  capacity  to  provide  satisfactory  urban  services  and  leading  to  poor  quality 
urbanization and underutilization of urban economic potential. 
 
8.  Government’s policy direction. Urbanization in India is an important determinant of 
national economic growth and poverty reduction. To address the country’s urban challenges, the 
government launched AMRUT 2.0, one of the key national missions focused on universal delivery 
of basic services. AMRUT 2.0 aims to provide support for (i) 100% water supply to all households 
via  taps,  (ii)  100%  wastewater  management,  and  (iii)  100%  sanitation  and  solid  waste 
management.  The  mission  also  promotes  wastewater  recycling  and  reuse  and  waterbody 
conservation. While the government’s commitment to provide financial support to the urban sector 
continues, the approach to funding is undergoing a transition. The government is shifting its 
funding approach from input-based to outcome-based, focusing on universal delivery of basic 
urban services. AMRUT 2.0 is also linking its incentive grants with key urban reforms that include 
improving water resources management, local revenue mobilization, promoting public–private 
partnerships, and wastewater reuse and value capture financing. 
 
9.  The proposed program, through the technical assistance (TA), will provide two tiers of 
support. The first tier is support to MOHUA for (i) developing various guidelines and establishing 
monitoring mechanisms for the implementation of AMRUT 2.0; (ii) capturing lessons from the 
implementation of AMRUT 2.0; and (iii) strengthening the capacity of the AMRUT 2.0 program 
management unit. The second tier of the support is to facilitate the actual implementation of the 
intended reforms under AMRUT 2.0 in states and ULBs. The TA will work with selected states 
and  ULBs  in  preparing  investment  plans  required  under  AMRUT  2.0  and  providing 
recommendations on safeguards assessment and monitoring. The expectation is that the plans 
and projects prepared under the TA support will serve as models to be replicated by other states 
and ULBs.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,670,000 of which $1,500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, and other in-kind 
contributions. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate the consultants (para. 14). The TA facility will be implemented over 30 months from 
January 2022. ADB will undertake periodic review missions to confirm the progress of TA activities.

14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.13 The TA will require about 163 person-months of consulting services 
(16 person-months of international consultants and 147 person-months of national consultants), 
with a mix of consulting firm and individual consultants.14 A firm will be recruited using the quality- 
and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10, and individuals will be 
recruited using individual consultant selection. A simplified technical proposal will be used for the 
selection of a firm.
